paper_title: Ultrathin Co0.85Se nanosheet cocatalyst for visible-light CO2 photoreduction

catalyst.source: 8 mg Ru(bpy) 3 Cl 2 6H 2 O and a certain amount of Co 0.85 Se were added to a solution of triethanolamine (TEOA)/water/acetonitrile (1 mL/2 mL/3 mL) in the 100 mL Schlenk flask reactor.
catalyst.context: Co 0.85 Se ultrathin nanosheets were fabricated by a simple solvothermal method.In a typical procedure, 1 mmol of Co(AC) 2 and 1 mmol of Na 2 SeO 3 were added into a solvent composed of 40 mL of DETA (diethylenetriamine) and 20 mL of deionized water with stirring, respectively.After further stirring for 30 min. in a beaker to dissolve completely, the homogeneous solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was sealed and maintained at 180 C for 12 h and then cooled to room temperature naturally.The resulting solid product was collected and washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol repeatedly.Then, the black product was obtained after freezedrying for further characterizations.The bulk Co 0.85 Se sample was synthesized by the same method without DETA. The Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was analyzed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with Cu K radiation.Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were collected on a Nova NanoSEM 230 microscopy (FEI Corp).Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was obtained using a JEOL JEM 2010 F microscope.Atomic force microscopy (AFM) was performed by means of a DI Innova Multimode SPM platform.UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-vis DRS) were measured on a Varian Cary 500 Scan UV-vis-NIR spectrophotometer.Photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy characterizations were carried out on an Edinburgh FL/FS900 spectrophotometer at room temperature.X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on an ESCALAB 250 photoelectron spectroscope system.The N 2 adsorption/desorption and CO 2 adsorption were measured with an ASAP2020 M apparatus. In the established photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reaction system, 300 W Xenon Lamp with 420 nm cut-off filter was used as light source.A circulation condensate equipment was employed to control the reaction temperature at 20C. 8 mg Ru(bpy) 3 Cl 2 6H 2 O and a certain amount of Co 0.85 Se were added to a solution of triethanolamine (TEOA)/water/acetonitrile (1 mL/2 mL/3 mL) in the 100 mL Schlenk flask reactor.A 300 W xenon lamp with 420 nm cut-off filter was utilized as the light source.Before light on, the whole reaction system was evacuated by a mechanical pump to ensure the air eliminated.CO 2 (99.999 purity) was then bubbled into the reactor with stirring for 10 min.to get a CO 2 -saturated solution.The produced gases were analyzed by a gas chromatography (Agilent 6890 N).The isotopic experiment was carried out by using 13 CO 2 as the reactant under otherwise identical conditions, and the products were analyzed by the gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS).

co-catalyst.source: Co 0.85 Se nanosheets have been found to be efficient cocatalysts for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction with TON as high as 58 in 1 h reaction under visible-light irradiation.
co-catalyst.context: Ultrathin Co 0.85 Se nanosheets were prepared via a facile solvothermal method, which successfully overcome the disadvantage of insufficient active sites in bulk Co 0.85 Se by reducing its thickness into the atomic scale.Co 0.85 Se nanosheets have been found to be efficient cocatalysts for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction with TON as high as 58 in 1 h reaction under visible-light irradiation.Compared with bulk Co 0.85 Se blocks, the ultrathin nanosheet samples exhibited nearly 2.5 times higher activity in CO 2 photoreduction.The metal-like character and ultrathin 2D structure of Co 0.85 Se nanosheets support the superb charges transfer and rich CO 2 adsorption sites exposure for surface catalysis.A relationship between the surface structure and the cocatalytic activity was established.These results not only demonstrate the potential of a notable, affordable and earth-abundant CO 2 photoreduction cocatalyst based on ultrathin Co 0.85 Se nanosheets but also provide a guidance in the exploration of excellent active and durable cocatalysts/catalysts to replace noble metals for artificial photosynthesis.

co-catalyst.source: 8 mg Ru(bpy) 3 Cl 2 6H 2 O and a certain amount of Co 0.85 Se were added to a solution of triethanolamine (TEOA)/water/acetonitrile (1 mL/2 mL/3 mL) in the 100 mL Schlenk flask reactor.
co-catalyst.context: Co 0.85 Se ultrathin nanosheets were fabricated by a simple solvothermal method.In a typical procedure, 1 mmol of Co(AC) 2 and 1 mmol of Na 2 SeO 3 were added into a solvent composed of 40 mL of DETA (diethylenetriamine) and 20 mL of deionized water with stirring, respectively.After further stirring for 30 min. in a beaker to dissolve completely, the homogeneous solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was sealed and maintained at 180 C for 12 h and then cooled to room temperature naturally.The resulting solid product was collected and washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol repeatedly.Then, the black product was obtained after freezedrying for further characterizations.The bulk Co 0.85 Se sample was synthesized by the same method without DETA. The Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was analyzed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with Cu K radiation.Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were collected on a Nova NanoSEM 230 microscopy (FEI Corp).Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was obtained using a JEOL JEM 2010 F microscope.Atomic force microscopy (AFM) was performed by means of a DI Innova Multimode SPM platform.UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-vis DRS) were measured on a Varian Cary 500 Scan UV-vis-NIR spectrophotometer.Photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy characterizations were carried out on an Edinburgh FL/FS900 spectrophotometer at room temperature.X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on an ESCALAB 250 photoelectron spectroscope system.The N 2 adsorption/desorption and CO 2 adsorption were measured with an ASAP2020 M apparatus. In the established photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reaction system, 300 W Xenon Lamp with 420 nm cut-off filter was used as light source.A circulation condensate equipment was employed to control the reaction temperature at 20C. 8 mg Ru(bpy) 3 Cl 2 6H 2 O and a certain amount of Co 0.85 Se were added to a solution of triethanolamine (TEOA)/water/acetonitrile (1 mL/2 mL/3 mL) in the 100 mL Schlenk flask reactor.A 300 W xenon lamp with 420 nm cut-off filter was utilized as the light source.Before light on, the whole reaction system was evacuated by a mechanical pump to ensure the air eliminated.CO 2 (99.999 purity) was then bubbled into the reactor with stirring for 10 min.to get a CO 2 -saturated solution.The produced gases were analyzed by a gas chromatography (Agilent 6890 N).The isotopic experiment was carried out by using 13 CO 2 as the reactant under otherwise identical conditions, and the products were analyzed by the gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS).

co-catalyst.source: For the first time, the as-prepared Co 0.85 Se was applied to be an efficient heterogeneous cocatalyst for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction under visible light irradiation.
co-catalyst.context: Ultrathin 2D Co 0.85 Se nanosheets have been successfully designed and synthesized via a simple solvothermal method.For the first time, the as-prepared Co 0.85 Se was applied to be an efficient heterogeneous cocatalyst for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction under visible light irradiation.Under the optimal reaction conditions, the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction system achieved a superior catalytic performance with a CO generation rate of 24.6 mol/h.Compared with the bulk Co 0.85 Se sample, the ultrathin 2D structure show much better activity towards CO 2 photoreduction by promoting the separation and transfer of photogenerated charge carriers, delivering large surface area for CO 2 adsorption, and exposing rich active sites for surface catalysis.The current work may inspire the development of transition metal compounds with ultrathin 2D nanosheet structure for artificial photosynthesis. Fig. 1.XRD patterns and crystal structure of Co 0.85 Se samples. Fig. 2. (a) SEM image, (b) TEM image, (c) HRTEM image, (d) SAED of Co 0.85 Se nanosheets samples. Fig. 3. AFM image and corresponding height profile of Co 0.85 Se nanosheets samples. Fig. 4. XPS spectra of Co 2p in Co 0.85 Se nanosheets samples. Fig. 5. N 2 adsorption/desorption isotherms (77 K) (a), and CO 2 adsorption isotherms (1 atm, 273 K) (b) of Co 0.85 Se nanosheets samples. Fig. 6.(a) Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity under various conditions; (b) Yield of CO and H 2 as a function of reaction time; (c) Stability test of Co 0.85 Se nanosheets samples in six repeats of photocatalytic reaction; (d) Dependence of the wavelength of incident light on the evolution of CO and H 2 . Fig.7.GC-MS analysis for the produced CO from the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reaction using 13 CO 2 . This work is financially supported by the scientific research startup fund of Shannxi University of Science and Technology, and the Open Project Program of the State Key Laboratory of Photocatalysis on Energy and Environment (Grant No. SKLPEE-KF201809) Fuzhou University. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cattod.2018.11.017.

light source.source: Co 0.85 Se nanosheets have been found to be efficient cocatalysts for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction with TON as high as 58 in 1 h reaction under visible-light irradiation.
light source.context: Ultrathin Co 0.85 Se nanosheets were prepared via a facile solvothermal method, which successfully overcome the disadvantage of insufficient active sites in bulk Co 0.85 Se by reducing its thickness into the atomic scale.Co 0.85 Se nanosheets have been found to be efficient cocatalysts for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction with TON as high as 58 in 1 h reaction under visible-light irradiation.Compared with bulk Co 0.85 Se blocks, the ultrathin nanosheet samples exhibited nearly 2.5 times higher activity in CO 2 photoreduction.The metal-like character and ultrathin 2D structure of Co 0.85 Se nanosheets support the superb charges transfer and rich CO 2 adsorption sites exposure for surface catalysis.A relationship between the surface structure and the cocatalytic activity was established.These results not only demonstrate the potential of a notable, affordable and earth-abundant CO 2 photoreduction cocatalyst based on ultrathin Co 0.85 Se nanosheets but also provide a guidance in the exploration of excellent active and durable cocatalysts/catalysts to replace noble metals for artificial photosynthesis.
